Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Evolution of virulence in a host-pathogen system
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will improve our understanding of the evolution of infectious disease systems while also contributing to education and the development of conservation strategies for protecting amphibian diversity. Disease epidemics rarely end in the complete extinction of host populations. Especially in highly lethal diseases, theory predicts a shift away from the outbreak phase to a post-outbreak stage where hosts and pathogens persist in a shared environment. Such transitions in disease states present a moving target that limits the development of successful intervention strategies. This research investigates the factors that drive evolutionary shifts in disease dynamics by focusing on one of the most devastating infectious diseases of vertebrates in recorded history, amphibian chytridiomycosis. Chytridiomycosis is caused by a fungal pathogen that can spread rapidly through amphibian populations and cause extremely high levels of mortality, suggesting that it is a strong agent of natural selection. This disease has caused - and continues to cause - dramatic losses of amphibian biodiversity around the world. The investigators are using an in-depth understanding of chytridiomycosis to develop science-based conservation strategies. The research is integrated with educational outreach, including public workshops and presentations centered on the annual International Save the Frogs Day.

This research capitalizes on a decade of research in Central America and on an unprecedented archive of disease data, pathogen isolates, and host samples. Pathogen isolates and host samples were collected and archived during the outbreak phase of the disease and similar data are being collected during the endemic phase, beginning eight to ten years later. The researchers are using experimental and molecular methods to investigate the hypotheses that (1) the level of pathogen virulence has shifted since the original outbreaks and (2) that hosts have evolved to be more tolerant of infection. To test these hypotheses, the investigators are testing the historic and contemporary samples to identify phenotypic and genetic differences linked to pathogen virulence host immune defenses. The results will provide insights for safeguarding amphibian biodiversity and for understanding the role of evolution in shaping post-epidemic dynamics of emerging infectious diseases.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A shift in virulence, or transition away from the outbreak phase of a disease toward the stable coexistence of host and pathogen often occurs after the emergence of highly infectious pathogens yet the mechanism that drive this shift remain unclear. The central focus of this project was to understand the factors that have shaped the dynamics of amphibian host populations following an outbreak of the fungal disease chytridiomycosis in Panama. Chytridiomycosis, caused by the fungal pathogen Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis, is one of several recently-emerged and globally important pathogens that threatens wildlife. Thus, our goal was to provide new insights into the mechanisms that govern the long-term dynamics of wildlife host-pathogen interactions.

We tested the hypotheses that (1) a decrease in the pathogenicity of the fungal pathogen and (2) an increase in the effectiveness of host defenses shaped the recovery of susceptible host populations in the decade that has passed since the initial disease-related die-offs occurred. Results our field surveys suggest that contemporary infection patterns do not fit the classic models for endemic host-pathogen systems. Rather than a shift to high pathogen prevalence, we found that prevalence has decreased since the outbreak, though the pathogen remains present in all study populations, even those of host species considered highly susceptible to this disease. When we compared pathogen samples collected during initial die-offs to those present in contemporary amphibian populations we found no evidence for a decrease in pathogenicity. All isolates remained highly lethal to naiive susceptible host species and we found no evidence for genetic changes in the pathogen since the outbreak. Instead we found evidence for changes in host defenses in the decade since the outbreak, and our experiments demonstrated the importance of these defenses to disease outcomes for susceptible species. Taken together, our results suggest that shifts in host defenses have played a more important role in the persistence of amphibian populations following this disease outbreak than changes in the pathogen.

The results of this work provide new insights for safeguarding amphibian biodiversity against this newly-emerged and global pathogen, as well as for understanding the role of host and pathogen evolution in shaping the post-epidemic dynamics of emerging infectious diseases. The project also enabled us to train undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers, many of whom come from underrepresented groups in the STEM fields, in laboratory, field and computational methods. Our research findings have been disseminated broadly through publications, talks at scientific meetings, engagement with the amphibian conservation community, and community outreach activities.
